WRITING.TEXT: Her name is Chloe, and she was a veiled chameleon I had in college. She passed away while in the care of a friend of mine.

Overall good pet, fun to hold and to watch for hours on end. Lots of maintenance to think about though, both in feeding, cage cleaning, and dealing with a heat lamp. Also, so many care steps means getting someone to take care of it while on vacation is tricky as well.

WRITING.TITLE: Watching her hunt for lunch everyday was definitely a highlight!

WRITING.TEXT: Does everyone on Reddit drive a friggin Subaru??
You might look at Stanford University's online CS106A. It's on iTunes U and the professor assumes nothing about prior experience. He's pretty funny too.
I hope the "Bradley" spelling error is intentional. That show is just perfect.
Relevant xkcd: https://xkcd.com/1329/

I'm current in the middle of the O'Reilly School of Technology Java 3 online class and I was super bummed it is being closed at the end of the year. Is there anything available with real human teachers and assignments for Java I can take for the advanced algorithms / data structures?

I plan to as soon as I find something better, but I'm building a solid Java foundation and some side-projects to make sure I get in the right next job. One of the "problems" is that I am paid really well right now! My dad calls it "golden handcuffs".

I wish I had asked this before taking my current job. I'm modifying a legacy ERP system's code using ridiculously outdated tools (they look like windows 98), while not developing any marketable technical skills in the meantime.
This looks amazing! I'm packing my bags for Finland! Oh wait, I can do it from home?

Codingbat is really good for "method" practice, especially since you type right in the browser without any help from an IDE, but it doesn't help with classes, inheritance, polymorphism, or anything beyond what a single method can achieve. There are hilarious "epic progress graphs" where you can see someone who attempted a certain problem for days or weeks at a time failing over and over again, it's a nice touch from the developer to include that. I will look at codeabbey since I do need "learning by example" to really get unstuck from my current Java skill level.
Congrats!

WRITING.TITLE: Prefacing anything with "I'm sure" implies uncertainty
WRITING.TEXT: Take it out and you suddenly sound certain.
I was making a joke (the typical comparison to the end of the world is ridiculous, but here it can be taken literally)...

This actually works 100% of the time for 30 second pick removal! 1. With the guitar flat on its back (strings up), shake the guitar to get the pick into the middle (just like your photo). 2. CAREFULLY Swing the guitar around above your head keeping the strings facing you in a way that puts centrifugal force on the pick keeping it in the center until the top, then when you stop it may fall out through the hole and you're done. Much like a kid on a swingset who swings too high, the falls down. 3. If it doesn't fall out, at least it's close to the hole, so just bounce it around toward the hole for a few seconds to see if you were close. If not, repeat step 2! If I get enough upvotes I'll make a video of this.
This game is actually about the end of the world...

Here are some questions to ask: "Would I care about this photo in 10 years?". If you assume no to that question until you see a good one, flag it, and keep the flagged ones only. If you are worried about changing you mind, put all the rejects into a separate folder, in a place you go to when you need to free up space. Then a reject has a chance of being resurrected as long as you haven't deleted the rejects folder it lives in.
Alcoholistic tendencies. Any comment or joke about over-drinking always get s a laugh, and the more you can drink, the more respect you get.
Ah ha, but mine is 4321!

WRITING.TITLE: The Target store brand "up up" sends the opposite message when turned upside down

Can a sharpie be left IN the fridge? That would remove the ugly string part of this LPT.

WRITING.TITLE: LPT: When culling a large set of photos, review them in reverse order (newest photos first). You usually only keep the last one you took in any group of repeats.
WRITING.TEXT: BONUS TIP: If you have a large set of photos and you need to get rid of more than half, use an "opt in" process where you only keep the ones you flag instead of "opt out" where you delete the ones you don't want. A great tool for this is Photo Mechanic (not free, but worth it). Source: I am a wedding / event photographer so I often need to reduce a set of 2k-5k photos down by 80%.
